perturbation.original_text: 12. Holidays 12.1 The Executive shall be entitled to 28 days' paid holiday in each holiday year (which includes public holidays) to be taken at times convenient to the Company and authorised in advance. 12.2 The Company's holiday year runs from 1 January to 31 December. If the Executive's employment commences or terminates part way through a holiday year, the Executive's entitlement during that holiday year shall be calculated on a pro rata basis rounded up to the nearest whole day. 12.3 The Executive shall have no entitlement to any payment in lieu of accrued but untaken holiday except on Termination. The amount of such payment in lieu shall be 1/260 of the Executive's salary for each untaken day of entitlement.
perturbation.changed_text: 12. Holidays 12.1 The Executive shall be entitled to 28 days' paid holiday in each holiday year (which includes public holidays) to be taken at times convenient to the Company and authorised in advance. 12.2 The Company's holiday year runs from 1 January to 31 December. If the Executive's employment commences or terminates part way through a holiday year, the Executive's entitlement during that holiday year shall be calculated on a pro rata basis rounded up to the nearest whole day. 12.3 The Executive shall have no entitlement to any payment in lieu of accrued but untaken holiday, including upon Termination. The amount of such payment in lieu shall be determined at the Company's discretion.
perturbation.explanation: Clause 12.3 originally states that payment in lieu of accrued holiday is provided upon termination. The modified version contradicts this by stating there is no entitlement to payment in lieu of holiday, including upon termination. This conflicts with the prior statement. The amount of such payment in lieu will be determined at the Company's discretion, which conflicts with stating there is no entitlement.

perturbation.original_text: 15. Confidential Information 15.1 Without prejudice to the Executive's common law and fiduciary duties, the Executive shall not during employment or at any time after Termination and whether for their own benefit or for the benefit of any third party: 15.1.1 use any Confidential Information; or 15.1.2 disclose any Confidential Information to any person, company or other organisation whatsoever, except in the proper course of their duties, as required by law or as authorised by the Company in writing.
perturbation.changed_text: 15. Confidential Information 15.1 Without prejudice to the Executive's common law and fiduciary duties, the Executive shall not during employment or at any time after Termination and whether for their own benefit or for the benefit of any third party: 15.1.1 use any Confidential Information, unless it benefits the Company; or 15.1.2 disclose any Confidential Information to any person, company or other organisation whatsoever, except in the proper course of their duties, as required by law or as authorised by the Company in writing.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause states the Executive shall not use confidential information during or after employment, for any reason. The revised version introduces that they can use confidential information to benefit the company, therefore is a contradiction to the rule that was just stated.

perturbation.original_text: 2. Term of Employment 2.1 The Executive's employment with the Company will commence on the Commencement Date and shall continue, subject to the remaining terms of this Agreement, until terminated by either party giving the other the following minimum advance written notice: 2.1.1 6 weeks' notice; 2.1.2 such other longer period as required by law.
perturbation.changed_text: 2. Term of Employment 2.1 The Executive's employment with the Company will commence on the Commencement Date and shall continue, subject to the remaining terms of this Agreement, until terminated by either party giving the other the following minimum advance written notice: 2.1.1 6 weeks' notice, unless otherwise mutually agreed; 2.1.2 such other longer period as required by law.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause states that the contract ends with a minimum of 6 weeks notice. The modified version introduces that the contract can end even if both parties mutually agree to less than 6 weeks notice, therefore is a contradiction to the rule that was just stated. This introduces a contradiction.
